Intelligence is, when you come across something you don’t understand, exploring it with your mind as opposed to saying “I don’t get it.” and shutting down (which is what I used to do). Intelligence is recognising that evil is relative. Accepting people’s lives who’re total opposites to yourself. Standing back from a situation and evaluating it. Intelligence is questioning everything. Nothing in life is simple. Question everything and then try to answer your own questions. “Why am I being told this? Is this influencing me in a specific way? It didn’t work the first time, what else can I do? Am I switched on? What is the most efficient way to pack this suitcase?” Most of all, intelligence is your brain. How much you can think about things. It’s not mindlessly reading through a book to memorise everything, it’s thinking “What are the key points here? How can I remind myself of these if I need to? It’s realising that your brain shuts down when you don’t understand something instead of working it out. Your intelligence is your brain and your wisdom is your spirit. To become more of either is knowing what they are, and switching your internal thought processes to align with both.

Mindfulness is ‘living in the present’ without getting caught in the painful past events or worrying about the future because these habits make our mind polluted, biased and restrain us to see the true nature of things. On the other hand if we focus on what is happening in “the present” we have an unbiased mind that gives us clear directions as to how, when or whether we should act. It is said that Einstein’s toddler son asked him whether he could jump from the first floor to his living room below. Einstein who was in deep thought said, “Yes.” The boy broke his leg! Wisdom is abundance of commonsense propelled by Mindfulness. Mindfulness gives us the sense of being just and encourages us to be impartial. It makes us aware of the importance of first evaluating things and situations before acting. What we call Emotional Intelligence percolates out of Mindfulness. Mindfulness makes us ‘respond’ and not ‘react’ to situations. It makes our conversation desirous and communication effective. It is because of these very reasons, Mindfulness is has been embraced by Lord Buddha and made it the centre pillar of Buddhism. The most important aspect of Mediation is to get our wandering mind to the present and for that the practitioners learn to focus on the breathing first. Being able to think for yourself, hold an argument, and form your own opinion even if it isn't a popular one. Is using logic even when you don't think logic is needed. Thinking things through without knowing it. Knowing your first reaction typically isn't the reaction you want to stick with. Knowing there are actually three sides to every story. One side by each party and then the truth. Because both parties will minimize their own fault in the situation. No matter the situation. Unless its a good one. Then everyone scrambles to get the most credit. Its also having a good moral compass. Being an honest man, even when its rough and the more difficult route to take. And yes, all of this is intelligence. It also means don't stop asking questions. Being open to the idea of learning something new, and being ready to fall and ready to fail, but ready and eager to try again and get it right the next time because you learned why you'd failed the first time. All intelligence.

Wisdom is easy said than done. By in large, a person becomes more wiser with experience, age, handling difficult situations and challenges. Wisdom can be taught, for sure, yes. There are lot of advises, information and lectures, however, you have to experience life, take challenges, fail and succeed for getting real wisdom. Meet people, talk to them (elder people, a social worker, nurse, nun/sister, your ex boss/first boss, your college professor, old teacher, etc…). Reading books is one way to get some knowledge. You have plenty of options to choose from. One book which I like is “Flow” by Mihaly Cskszentmihalyi. Go on a trip with least amount of money. Take only your bare essentials and go out for 10–15 days. Take a road trip. You will learn a lot about life, people, their difficulties and also how they can be still happy (if they are). Get your hands dirty. Go out……

Failures, brutal life lessons and an indomitable spirit. Add a low BS threshold and an insatiable quest for knowledge and adventure. Living and experiencing life's highs and lows. Humility and a surrendering of the ego, mentorship. Seek out the wise and make their acquaintance. Make sure your bookshelf is bigger than your T.V. Travel. Learn a new language, play a musical instrument as these enlarge your cultural circles and perspectives. Don't judge people who're struggling, love them and learn from them. Be one with everything. Ask the veil be lifted. Volunteer, there's real magic in the love-loop. I am 61 and I am just saying what works for me. Open heart and mind a prerequisites.

Plan. Execute. Fail. Learn. Put yourself in difficult situations and navigate yourself out of the mess. Talk to people different than you. Spend a lot of time alone and learn to be happy by yourself.
